book.name: 2 Thessalonians
book.description: THE SECOND EPISTLE OF PAUL TO THE THESSALONIANS
book.info: Approximately A.D. 54, as with the first Epistle ([link]1:1[/link]).
book.subject: Encouragement and Correction concerning the Holy Life for the Church Life

outlines.outline: The Content — Encouragement and Correction concerning the Holy Life for the Church
Encouragement — A Life Worthy of the Kingdom of God
Correction — The Misconception concerning the Day of the Lord's Coming

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Paul and Silvanus and Timothy to the [note]1[/note]church of the [note]2[/note]Thessalonians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ:
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Thes. 1[/link].
See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Thes. 1[/link].

verse.text: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

We ought to [xref]a[/xref]thank God always concerning you, brothers, even as it is fitting, because your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]faith grows exceedingly and the love of each one of you all to one another is increasing,
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Thes. 1[/link]. In the first Epistle to the Thessalonians, faith and love were considered constructing elements of the believers' life for the church. Here, in this Epistle, faith and love are growing and increasing in the Thessalonians' Christian life.

verse.text: So that we ourselves [xref]a[/xref]boast in you among the churches of God concerning your [note]1[/note]endurance and faith in all your [xref]b[/xref]persecutions and the afflictions which you bear,
verse.note: The endurance issued from and was supported by the hope of the Lord's coming back ([link]1 Thes. 1:3[/link]). Such endurance resulting from hope is always accompanied by faith. Hence, the phrase [i]endurance and faith[/i] is used here. Both endurance and faith are needed in persecutions and afflictions.

verse.text: A plain [xref]a[/xref]indication of the [note]1[/note]righteous judgment of God, that you may be accounted [xref]b[/xref]worthy of the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]kingdom of God, for which also you suffer;
verse.note: God's judgment is righteous and just upon all men. It will be finalized in the future ([link]Rom. 2:5-9[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]). The way God deals with different people in this age is an indication, a token, a proof, of the future execution of His righteous judgment.

The believers have been called into God's kingdom and glory ([link]1 Thes. 2:12[/link]). To enter into this kingdom, we need to pass through afflictions ([link]Acts 14:22[/link]). Hence, the persecutions and afflictions are a plain indication of God's righteous judgment, showing that we may be accounted worthy of the kingdom of God.

verse.text: Since [i]it is[/i] just with God to repay with affliction those afflicting you,

And to you who are being afflicted, [note]1[/note]rest with us at the [xref]a[/xref]revelation of the Lord Jesus from [xref]b[/xref]heaven with the [xref]c[/xref]angels of His power, in flaming [xref]d[/xref]fire,
verse.note: Or, relief, ease, repose, liberty. In this age the believers suffer persecutions and troubles for the Lord. At the Lord's coming back they will be relieved of their sufferings and will enter into the Lord's rest and enjoy its liberty.

verse.text: Rendering vengeance to those who do [xref]a[/xref]not know God and to those who do not [xref]b[/xref]obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus [note]1[/note]Christ.
verse.note: Some MSS omit, Christ.

verse.text: They will pay the penalty of eternal [xref]a[/xref]destruction from the [note]1[/note]presence of the Lord and from the [xref]b[/xref]glory of His strength
verse.note: Lit., face.

verse.text: When He [xref]a[/xref]comes to be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]glorified in His saints and to be marveled at in all those who have believed (because our [xref]c[/xref]testimony to you was believed) in [xref]d[/xref]that day.
verse.note: The Lord is the Lord of glory ([link]1 Cor. 2:8[/link]); He was glorified in His resurrection and ascension ([link]John 17:1[/link]; [link]Luke 24:26[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:9[/link]). Now He is in us as the hope of glory ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]) to bring us into glory ([link]Heb. 2:10[/link]). At His coming back, on the one hand He will come from the heavens with glory ([link]Rev. 10:1[/link]; [link]Matt. 25:31[/link]), and on the other hand He will be glorified in His saints; that is, His glory will be manifested from within His members, causing their body of humiliation to be transfigured into His glory, conforming it to the body of His glory ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]). Thus, the unbelievers will marvel at Him, admire Him, wonder at Him, in us, His believers.

verse.text: For which also we [xref]a[/xref]pray always concerning you, that our God may count you [xref]b[/xref]worthy of your calling and may fulfill in [xref]c[/xref]power [i]your[/i] every [note]1[/note]good intention for goodness and [i]your[/i] [xref]d[/xref]work of faith,
verse.note: Or, delight. The apostles prayed that God might fulfill the good intention, the delight, of the Thessalonians for goodness.

verse.text: So that the [xref]a[/xref]name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in Him, according to the [note]1[/note]grace of our God and the Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: The grace of our God and the Lord Jesus Christ is the Lord Himself within us as our life and life supply that we may live a life that will glorify the Lord and cause us to be glorified in Him. See notes [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in John 1[/link], [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link], and [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Cor. 13[/link].

verse.text: Now we ask you, brothers, [note]1[/note]with regard to the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]coming of our Lord Jesus Christ and our [xref]b[/xref]gathering together [note]3[/note]to Him,
verse.note: Or, on behalf of.

Gk. [i]parousia,[/i] meaning [i]presence.[/i] See notes [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Thes. 2[/link] and [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link]. Two matters are covered here: the Lord's parousia (presence) and our gathering together (rapture) to Him. The Lord's parousia will begin with the rapture of the overcomers to the throne of God in heaven ([link]Rev. 12:5-6[/link]); at the end of the great tribulation, which will occur in the last three and a half years of this age, the second half of the last week in [link]Dan. 9:27[/link] ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link] and note; [link]Rev. 11:2[/link] and note 4), it will come to the air ([link]Rev. 10:1[/link] and note 2) and last for a time; and it will end with its manifestation, "the manifestation of His parousia" ([link]v. 8[/link]; [link]Matt. 24:30[/link] and note 4). During the time in which the Lord's parousia remains in the air, the majority of the believers will be raptured to meet the Lord there ([link]1 Thes. 4:17[/link]). According to the context, [i]the day of the Lord[/i] in [link]v. 2[/link] refers to the day of the Lord's parousia (coming), in which the rapture of the majority of the believers will occur. [link]Verse 3[/link] tells us affirmatively that before that day Antichrist will be revealed to play the major role in the great tribulation ([link]v. 4[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:1-8[/link], [link]12-15[/link]). This reveals clearly and definitely that the Lord's coming (parousia) to the air and the rapture of the majority of the believers cannot take place before the great tribulation.
Lit., toward.

verse.text: That you be not quickly shaken [note]1[/note]in mind nor alarmed, neither by a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit nor by word nor by a letter as if by us, to the effect that the [note]3[/note]day of the Lord has come.
verse.note: Lit., from the mind; i.e., "from a steady and soberly judging mind" (Darby).
Referring to a speaking spirit that pretends and claims to have the authority of divine revelation.
See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Thes. 5[/link].

verse.text: Let no one [note]1[/note]deceive you in any way, because [i]it will not come[/i] unless the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]apostasy comes first and the [note]3[/note]man of [xref]b[/xref]lawlessness is revealed, the [xref]c[/xref]son of [xref]d[/xref]perdition,
verse.note: Or, beguile; "not only making a false impression, but actually leading astray" (Vincent).
I.e., falling away (from the straight way of God's economy as revealed in the Scriptures).

Antichrist, as prophesied in [link]Dan. 7:20-21[/link], [link]24-26[/link]; [link]9:27[/link]; [link]11:36-37[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:1-8[/link], [link]12-18[/link]; [link]19:19-20[/link]. He will be the man of lawlessness and will change laws, destroy and corrupt many to an extraordinary degree, blaspheme God, and deceive men. Hence, the Lord will utterly destroy him, and he will become the son of perdition.

verse.text: Who opposes and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]exalts himself above all that is called [xref]b[/xref]God or an object of worship, so that he [xref]c[/xref]sits in the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]temple of God, setting himself forth, [i]saying[/i] that [xref]e[/xref]he is God.
verse.note: This fulfills the prophecy concerning Antichrist in [link]Dan. 11:36-37[/link]. This will take place in the second half of the last week, as prophesied in [link]Dan. 9:27[/link]. See note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link].
This is "the holy place" in [link]Matt. 24:15[/link], indicating that the temple of God will be rebuilt before the Lord comes back.

verse.text: Do you not remember that while I was still with you, I said these things to you?
And now you know that which [note]1[/note]restrains, so that he might be revealed in his own [note]2[/note]time.
verse.note: This refers to some power that hinders the revelation of the man of lawlessness, Antichrist.
The time appointed by God, which will be the last of the seventy weeks, as prophesied in [link]Dan. 9:27[/link]; [link]7:24-26[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:1-8[/link].

verse.text: For [i]it is[/i] the [note]1[/note]mystery of [xref]a[/xref]lawlessness [i]that[/i] is now operating, [i]but[/i] only until the one now restraining [note]2[/note]goes out of the way.
verse.note: The lawlessness that will characterize Antichrist ([link]v. 3[/link]) is already operating in this age mysteriously. It is the mystery of lawlessness working today among the nations and in human society.
This probably means that the restraining one is taken out of the way.

verse.text: And then the [xref]a[/xref]lawless one will be revealed (whom the Lord Jesus will [note]1[/note]slay by the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]breath of His [xref]c[/xref]mouth and [xref]d[/xref]bring to nothing by the [note]3[/note]manifestation of His [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]coming),
verse.note: This will be fulfilled in [link]Rev. 19:19-20[/link].
The same Greek word as for [i]spirit.[/i]

Or, shining forth. This indicates that the Lord's coming (parousia) will be hidden before it is manifested openly (see note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link]). This indicates also that the Lord's coming will last a period of time (see note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link]). First, it will be in secret, and then it will be manifested to the public.
See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: The coming of whom is [note]1[/note]according to Satan's operation in all [xref]a[/xref]power and [xref]b[/xref]signs and wonders of a [note]2[/note]lie
verse.note: As prophesied in [link]Rev. 13:2[/link], [link]4[/link], [link]7[/link].
The entire operation of Satan to deceive people ([link]v. 10[/link]) is in its totality a lie, just as he is a liar and the father of liars ([link]John 8:44[/link]).

verse.text: And in all deceit of unrighteousness among those who are [xref]a[/xref]perishing, because they did not receive the love of the truth that they might be saved.
And [note]1[/note]because of this God [xref]a[/xref]sends to them an operation of error that they might believe the [xref]b[/xref]lie,
verse.note: Because the perishing ones did not receive the love of the truth, which God intended to give them that they might be saved ([link]v. 10[/link]), God sends to them an operation of error, an active power of misleading, that they might believe the lie.

verse.text: So that all who have not believed the [xref]a[/xref]truth but have taken [note]1[/note]pleasure in unrighteousness might be judged.
verse.note: The believers have a good intention for goodness ([link]1:11[/link]); the perishing ones ([link]v. 10[/link]), who reject the truth of God, take pleasure in unrighteousness. To sin is a delight to them ([link]Rom. 1:32[/link]).

verse.text: But we ought to [xref]a[/xref]thank God always concerning you, brothers [xref]b[/xref]beloved of the Lord, because God [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]chose you [note]2[/note]from the [xref]d[/xref]beginning unto [xref]e[/xref]salvation in [note]3[/note][xref]f[/xref]sanctification of the Spirit and [note]4[/note]belief of the [xref]g[/xref]truth,
verse.note: God loved us ([link]v. 16[/link]), chose us from the beginning, and called us through the gospel ([link]v. 14[/link]). He chose us unto His salvation, which is by sanctification of the Spirit, and He called us to the obtaining of the Lord's glory. Now He is taking us on with eternal comfort and good hope in grace.
I.e., from eternity past (cf. [link]Eph. 1:4[/link]). Some ancient MSS read, as firstfruits.

Sanctification of the Spirit consists of three steps: (1) the Spirit's seeking us and convicting us at the time that He caused us to repent and believe ([link]1 Pet. 1:2[/link]; [link]John 16:8[/link]); (2) His sanctifying us both positionally and dispositionally ([link]Heb. 13:12[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]) at the time we were saved; and (3) His sanctifying us dispositionally as we pursue the growth in life ([link]Rom. 6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]). By these three steps of the Spirit's sanctification, God's salvation is applied to us that we may obtain and enjoy it fully. The three steps of the Spirit's sanctification not only separate us from all old and negative things, making us holy unto God, but also sanctify us, making us a new creation full of the Lord's essence and element, that we may obtain the Lord's glory.

Or, faith. By the Spirit's sanctification God's salvation is revealed and brought to us; by our believing we receive all that is revealed and brought to us by the Spirit, so that we obtain God's salvation.

verse.text: To [note]1[/note]which also He [xref]a[/xref]called you through our [xref]b[/xref]gospel unto the obtaining of the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]glory of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: Referring to [i]salvation in sanctification[/i]... and belief... in the preceding verse. God chose us unto salvation in eternity, and then in time He called us unto the obtaining of the glory of our Lord. Salvation in sanctification of the Spirit and belief of the truth is the procedure; the obtaining of the glory of our Lord is the goal.

The glory of the Lord is that He, as the Son of God the Father, possesses the Father's life and nature that He may express the Father. To obtain the Lord's glory is to be in the same position as the Son of God that we may express the Father ([link]John 17:22[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: So then, brothers, [xref]a[/xref]stand firm and hold to the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]things which were handed down [i]to you and[/i] which you were taught, whether by word or by our letter.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 11[/link].

verse.text: Now our [note]1[/note]Lord Jesus Christ Himself and God our Father, who has [xref]a[/xref]loved us and given us [note]2[/note]eternal comfort and [note]3[/note]good [xref]b[/xref]hope in [note]4[/note]grace,
verse.note: Our Lord Jesus Christ and God the Father work together to comfort and establish the believers ([link]v. 17[/link]).
Not temporary and transitory comfort and strengthening but eternal comfort by the divine life. This comfort is sufficient for any kind of environment and situation; thus, it is with good hope.

The hope of glory ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]), which is the hope of the Lord's coming ([link]1 Thes. 1:3[/link]), when we will be either resurrected or transfigured into glory ([link]1 Thes. 4:13-14[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:10[/link]).

God Himself in Christ for us to enjoy (see note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in John 1[/link]) that we may be sanctified by His Spirit ([link]v. 13[/link]) and comforted and established ([link]v. 17[/link]) with eternal comfort and good hope.

verse.text: Comfort your hearts and [xref]a[/xref]establish [i]you[/i] in every good work and word.
Finally, brothers, [xref]a[/xref]pray concerning us, that the word of the Lord may [xref]b[/xref]run and be [note]1[/note]glorified, even as [i]it is[/i] also [note]2[/note]with you;
verse.note: To have the divine riches contained in the word of the Lord released and expressed in the believers' living.
Lit., toward.

verse.text: And that we may be [xref]a[/xref]delivered from unreasonable and evil men, for the [xref]b[/xref]faith does not belong to all.
But the Lord is [xref]a[/xref]faithful, who will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]establish you and [note]2[/note]guard [i]you[/i] from the [xref]c[/xref]evil one.
verse.note: By eternal comfort and good hope ([link]2:16-17[/link]).

The entire world lies in the evil one ([link]1 John 5:19[/link]), but the divine life, which we have by being born of God, keeps and guards us from him ([link]1 John 5:18[/link], [link]4[/link]; [link]3:8-9[/link]).

verse.text: And we have [xref]a[/xref]confidence in the Lord concerning you that what we [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]charge, you both are doing and will do.
verse.note: Such as the charges in [link]1 Thes. 4:2-4[/link], [link]9-12[/link]; [link]5:11-22[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:2[/link], [link]15[/link]; [link]3:6[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]12-15[/link].

verse.text: And the Lord [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]direct your [xref]b[/xref]hearts [note]2[/note]into the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]love of God and [note]4[/note]into the [note]5[/note]endurance of Christ.
verse.note: By the leading of the Spirit, through whom the love of God has been poured out into our hearts ([link]Rom. 8:14[/link]; [link]5:5[/link]).
I.e., to love God with the love of God that we have enjoyed and experienced.
Our love toward God, issuing from the love of God ([link]1 John 4:19[/link]) that has been poured out into our hearts.
I.e., to endure with the endurance of Christ that we have enjoyed and experienced.

On the positive side, we need to enjoy the love of God that we may love Him in order to live for Him, and on the negative side, we need to participate in the endurance of Christ that we may endure sufferings, as He did, to stand against Satan, the enemy of God. Loving God and enduring sufferings are excellent characteristics of a Christian living.

verse.text: Now we charge you, brothers, in the [xref]a[/xref]name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you [xref]b[/xref]keep away from every brother [note]1[/note]walking [xref]c[/xref]disorderly and not according to the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]things which were handed down [i]to you and[/i] which you received from us.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Thes. 5[/link]. Cf. [link]vv. 7[/link], [link]11[/link]. To walk disorderly not only is according to the flesh ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]) but also is against the building up of the church life ([link]1 Thes. 5:11[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:19[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:23[/link]).
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 11[/link].

verse.text: For you yourselves know how you ought to [xref]a[/xref]imitate us, because we were [note]1[/note]not disorderly among you;
verse.note: The apostles were for the building up of the church in all things ([link]2 Cor. 12:19[/link]); they were absolutely not disorderly among the believers but were a pattern for the believers to imitate ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: Nor did we eat bread [i]as[/i] a gift from anyone, but in [xref]a[/xref]labor and hardship we [xref]b[/xref]worked night and day so that we would not be [xref]c[/xref]burdensome to any of you;
Not because we do not have the [xref]a[/xref]right, but in order that we might give ourselves to you as a [xref]b[/xref]pattern that you might [xref]c[/xref]imitate us.
For even when we were with you, we gave you this [xref]a[/xref]charge, that if anyone does not want to work, neither should he [xref]b[/xref]eat.
For we hear of some walking among you [xref]a[/xref]disorderly, doing no work at all, but being [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]busybodies.
verse.note: They were busy but were doing no work at all; i.e., they were busy with only what was not their own business.

verse.text: Now such ones we [xref]a[/xref]charge and [xref]b[/xref]exhort in the Lord Jesus Christ to [xref]c[/xref]work with [xref]d[/xref]quietness and [xref]e[/xref]eat their own bread.
But you, brothers, do not [xref]a[/xref]lose heart in doing good.
And if anyone does [xref]a[/xref]not obey our word through this letter, mark this one so as [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]not to mingle with him, in order that he may be ashamed.
verse.note: I.e., not to have company, not to keep company.

verse.text: Yet do not regard [i]him[/i] as an enemy, but [xref]a[/xref]admonish [i]him[/i] as a brother.
Now the Lord of [xref]a[/xref]peace Himself give you [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]peace continually in every way. The Lord be [xref]c[/xref]with you all.
verse.note: By keeping the charge in [link]vv. 12-15[/link], the believers receive peace from the Lord continually in every way.

verse.text: The greeting in [xref]a[/xref]my own hand — Paul — which is the mark in every letter; so I write.
The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all.
verse.note: It is only when the Lord is enjoyed by us as grace that we can guard the church life from any kind of misleading and disorderliness. To live a proper church life and to keep the church life in order, we need to enjoy the Lord as the supplying grace. See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Thes. 5[/link].
